Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC CGI: Collaborative Research: Wood-Based Composites Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
I/UCRC for Wood-Based Composites Center

1035009 Virginia Polytechnic; Charles Frazier
1034975 Oregon State University; Frederick Kamke

The Center for Wood-Based Composites will focus on advancing the material science of wood and wood-based composites. Virginia Polytechnic (VT) and Oregon State University (OSU) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with VT as the lead institution.

The proposed Center will advance the materials science of wood and wood-based composites, by improving the understanding of how wood interacts with adhesives, sealants, and composite manufacturing variables. The Center will promote research in building systems, mechanical and adhesive fastening between wood and non-wood materials, as well as novel material testing and modeling. The PIs also intend to further establish an internationally recognized research center that can help shape public policy, as related to timber management, reforestation, and the reduction of fossil fuel usage by using the advanced products. The two institutions involved in the proposed center have experience in working with industrial partners and conducting research projects.

The development of more advanced wood-based composites to be used in applications that currently depend primarily on steel, aluminum or concrete would have a positive impact on the environment and help combat climate change. The proposed Center plans to attract graduate and undergraduate students from a variety of disciplines, and to provide them with an opportunity to interact with industry leaders, thus giving them an understanding of how to apply and transfer fundamental research and impact the industry and the economy.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision of the NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center for Wood Based Composites is to be the leading source for fundamental research and education in the field of wood-based composites. These composites include products such as plywood, laminated veneer lumber, cross-laminated timber, particleboard, fiberboard, as well as new products, all principally used to build and functionalize U.S. homes. We actively promote and coordinate research and education at Virginia Tech and Oregon State University, as well as other university partners. We also attract students to careers in the wood-based composites and adhesion industries and provide continuing education programs.

The Center has advanced the material science of wood and wood-based composites by improving our understanding of how wood interacts with adhesives, coatings, and composite manufacturing variables. This has been accomplished through pre-competitive research under the advisement of company representatives from the adhesives and composite manufacturing industries. At Virginia Tech a major emphasis has been the impact of new federal regulations on allowable formaldehyde emissions from wood-based composites, where the intention was to limit emissions from the adhesives used to make the composites. The latest regulations restrict allowable emissions to such low levels that the natural (biogenic) formaldehyde created by wood now impacts regulation compliance. Consequently, we studied the fundamental chemical mechanisms of how wood generates formaldehyde. We demonstrated that different tree types (like Virginia pine, radiata pine, and yellow-poplar) produce vastly different quantities of formaldehyde. We showed that these different trees produce formaldehyde through different mechanisms. We determined how formaldehyde generation in wood may be promoted and suppressed using simple chemical treatments. Overall this effort provided tangible strategies for companies to control and limit biogenic formaldehyde emissions. However, the scope and complexity of this problem require a continued effort. In another project, we studied an adhesive technology that has been used for over 80 years, but that was never subjected to fundamental scientific investigation. We revealed new insights that directly impacted business operations of our members, and we demonstrated that even old technologies can be renewed through the university/industry collaboration. We also developed a new adhesive analysis, now adopted by our industry members, that helps to improve production efficiency. Collectively these efforts led us to more detailed chemical studies of exotic woods and why they “stick” or bond poorly, and of simple materials like tree bark and wheat flour that are often formulated into wood adhesives. Aside from these successes, a major benefit was that our member companies cultivated new capabilities at Virginia Tech when we joined forces to solve industry problems. These new capabilities enhance the skills and career preparation for our students.

Timeless needs for warmth and shelter have made timber resources essential for human endeavor. Fossil fuels have supplanted wood for heating, but housing in North America still relies mostly on forest resources. The huge timbers that our ancestors needed are no longer available, and yet society’s reliance on wood-based materials is far greater today. Currently, composite materials are produced from smaller trees, plantation grown trees, and previously discarded trees. Wood is reduced to particles, flakes, strands, and sheets, and then reconsolidated to make composite beams, columns, panels, and many other products. This approach optimizes resource efficiency and also material performance. Opportunity lies not only in new shelter, but also in warmth and security through energy efficiency and carbon sequestration. In their manufacture, wood products consume far less fossil fuel than competitive materials. Furthermore, as CO2-reduction strategies develop, policy-makers and the public will realize that promotion of the forest products industry is an effective Earth-friendly strategy for carbon sequestration. Wise timber management, accelerated reforestation and afforestation, and the simultaneous transfer of carbon to durable wood products will play an essential role in CO2 reduction.

The Center not only stimulates technology, but also contributes to advancing societal goals by attracting graduate and undergraduate students from a variety of disciplines, including chemistry, materials science, engineering mechanics, civil engineering, and wood science, and then matriculating them through a rich and robust educational experience. Through graduate education and undergraduate research, the Center broadens the awareness of future scientists who otherwise would be unaware of the personal and societal rewards found in the wise use of timber resources. At Virginia Tech, the financial support provided by the Center has produced nine successful graduate degrees, with most graduates now serving our target industry. The undergraduate experience was also enriched for several students engaged in research either directly or indirectly through the Center. Currently, three graduate degrees are now in progress, and many more will follow as the Center continues to evolve in service to our industry.


Last Modified: 10/30/2016
Modified by: Charles E Frazier
